    • getGameStatus

      public ExecuteResult getGameStatus()

    • isValidProgram

      private boolean isValidProgram()
      Determines whether the current program in the program area is valid. This means there can only be one cluster for the main program, along possibly some function definitions. This is checked through the amount of open connectors. There can only be one free up connector, and there can no be open side connectors.
      Returns:
      true if the program is valid.

    • startExecution

      private void startExecution() throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException

    • initialiseStack

      private void initialiseStack()
      Creates the initial stack which we begin the program with. Retrieves all top-level blocks, and loops through them in *reverse*, pushing block by block on the stack. If we come across a while or an if, we push the boolean blocks one by one on the stack as well (so a while with an not-wallinfront will be pushed as a whileBlock, a notBlock, then the wall in front).

    • addBlocksToStack

      private void addBlocksToStack​(java.util.ArrayList<Block> blockList)
      Push the contents of blockList onto the stack. This function should be used instead of the built-in addAll() function to ensure the list is pushed in reverse, and right-connected blocks are added as well.
      Parameters:
      blockList - A list of blocks

    • addBooleans

      private void addBooleans​(ConditionBlock startBlock)
      push the conditions of startBlock step by step onto the stack
      Parameters:
      startBlock - a condition block

    • executeOneStep

      public void executeOneStep() throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
      Execute one step of the program. We assume the first F5 key does not execute anything yet, but only starts the execution
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException

    • executeBlock

      private void executeBlock​(Block blockToExecute)
      Executes blockToExecute. Each type of block has different behaviour: 1) An ActionBlock directly edits the GameWorld with an action 2) A not block flips the value of the last seen boolean 3) A wall in front block sets the last seen boolean value depending on whether there is a wall in front of the robot 4) A ConditionBlock looks at the last seen boolean (since we updated it in the previous execution step), and if it was true, puts the body of the ConditionBlock on the stack. If it was a While, the while itself gets put on the bottom of the stack as well, so we will execute it again once we finished executing the body.
      Parameters:
      blockToExecute - the to be executed block

    • isExecuting

      public boolean isExecuting()
      Returns:
      A boolean indicating whether this program is currently executing.

    • stopExecuting

      public void stopExecuting()
      Stop the execution of the program. If the user wants to stop while nothing is happening, we assume they want to see the initial position of the robot

    • getGameWorldSnapShot

      public GameWorld getGameWorldSnapShot()
      Returns:
      A snapshot of the current gameworld. This snapshot can be used to revert to a previous state later on.

    • setGameWorldSnapShot

      public void setGameWorldSnapShot​(GameWorld gw)
      Sets the current world to a given snapshot. Care must be taken as the gameworld will become this snapshot, and any references to the new gameworld will affect the snapshot as well. If wanting to set a gameworld to a given snapshot without the possibility of the snapshot changing because of any user input, pass this function a clone of the snapshot.
      Parameters:
      gw - The snapshot which the gameworld will become
